subject: Getting Quikscript out of the PUA
msgSnippet: The last time we discussed the possibility of getting Quikscript encoded in Unicode, there was a lot of FUD spread by the participants, myself most of all. I
messageBody:
The last time we discussed the possibility of getting Quikscript encoded in Unicode, there was a lot of FUD spread by the participants, myself most of all.


I was under the assumption that Quikscript, if it were added in a way that would make it dependent on Shavian, would use SHAVIAN LETTER THIGH (looks like a .Fee) for .Thaw. This would be an extraordinarily silly way to do it–it’d be as if Polish fonts all had a glyph that looks like ł for U+0077 LATIN SMALL LETTER W. So to see what Quikscript would look like on a machine with no Quikscript fonts installed, I wrote the attached passage using the sorts of letters one would use.


While I have a bit of trouble with .Eight, .I, .Oy, and .Out, they can be inferred from context and the rest is surprisingly readable. As far as I can tell, Michael Everson’s proposal would provide concrete benefits to us with a minimum of downsides.


As of this writing, the only OS that I know of that ships with Shavian fonts is OS X. iOS 8.1, Windows 8.1, and Android 4.0 don’t ship with any. As such, this problem will likely be limited to OS X machines in the near future. As always, if you’re putting Quikscript on the Web, the best thing to do is use @font-face. I don’t have any suggestions for Quikscript-in-email other than “only handle that mail on a desktop computer where you can install your own fonts.”


So. If Mr. Everson’s willing, should we try and get this in Unicode 8.0?
